message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient presents with symptoms of deep vein thrombosis (DVT), which can be confirmed by ultrasound of the right leg. D-dimer levels may be elevated in conditions other than DVT, and CT pulmonary angiography can be considered if DVT is confirmed and pulmonary embolism is suspected. Reassurance and supportive treatment alone are not appropriate for a suspected DVT.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s history and symptoms suggest deep vein thrombosis (DVT) which requires a diagnostic test for confirmation. Among the options, ultrasound of the right leg is the most appropriate initial test for DVT diagnosis. D-dimer level can be falsely elevated in patients with tuberculosis and smoking history, and CT pulmonary angiography is not necessary at this time as there are no signs or symptoms of pulmonary embolism.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The sudden onset of pain and swelling in the leg, history of trauma, and presence of erythema and pitting edema suggest deep vein thrombosis (DVT). The absence of increased resistance or pain in the right calf in response to forced dorsiflexion of the right foot makes a DVT less likely. However, an ultrasound of the right leg is the best next step to confirm or exclude DVT. Reassurance and supportive treatment is not appropriate without further evaluation. D-dimer levels may be elevated in many conditions other than DVT and are not specific for DVT. CT pulmonary angiography is indicated in suspected pulmonary embolism, which is not suggested by the patient's presentation.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and history suggest deep vein thrombosis (DVT), which requires prompt diagnosis and treatment to prevent complications such as pulmonary embolism. The gold standard for diagnosis of DVT is ultrasound of the leg. D-dimer level may be elevated in many conditions, including DVT, but a normal D-dimer level does not rule out DVT. CT pulmonary angiography is indicated if pulmonary embolism is suspected. Reassurance and supportive treatment are not appropriate as DVT is a potentially serious condition.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms suggest deep vein thrombosis (DVT). The best next step is an ultrasound of the right leg to confirm the diagnosis of DVT. D-dimer level testing can be useful but it has low specificity and can be elevated in other conditions such as infections or surgery. CT pulmonary angiography is not necessary at this time as there are no symptoms suggestive of pulmonary embolism. Reassurance and supportive treatment should only be considered if the ultrasound is negative for DVT.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest deep vein thrombosis (DVT) and ultrasound is the best initial step to diagnose DVT. D-dimer levels can be elevated in many conditions and cannot confirm DVT. CT pulmonary angiography is used for diagnosis of pulmonary embolism. Reassurance and supportive treatment is not appropriate for a suspected DVT.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and physical examination suggest deep vein thrombosis (DVT). While D-dimer level and CT pulmonary angiography are options to rule out pulmonary embolism, ultrasound of the right leg is the best next step in the management of this patient to confirm or exclude DVT.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms indicate deep vein thrombosis (DVT), and the best initial test to confirm this is an ultrasound of the right leg. While a D-dimer level can also be used, it has lower specificity and may lead to unnecessary imaging tests. CT pulmonary angiography is indicated when there are signs and symptoms of pulmonary embolism, which are not present in this case.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has symptoms and physical findings suggestive of deep vein thrombosis (DVT), which requires prompt diagnosis and management to prevent pulmonary embolism. The best next step in management is an ultrasound of the right leg, which is highly sensitive and specific for DVT. D-dimer level is not specific enough to rule out DVT and CT pulmonary angiography is not needed at this stage. Reassurance and supportive treatment is not appropriate given the potential severity of the condition.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient presents with symptoms of deep vein thrombosis (DVT), which requires further assessment. While D-dimer level might be a useful test in some cases to confirm or rule out DVT, it has low specificity and false positives are common. Ultrasound of the right leg is the test of choice for diagnosing DVT. CT pulmonary angiography is used to diagnose pulmonary embolism, which is a complication of DVT but not necessarily present in all cases. Reassurance and supportive treatment are not appropriate without ruling out DVT.
